TextView.android:text: Bluebells are perennial flowering plants commonly referring to Hyacinthoides non-scripta in the family Asparagaceae, though other related species like Hyacinthoides hispanica and Mertensia virginica are also called bluebells. They are known for their nodding, bell-shaped blue to violet flowers that grow in dense, one-sided clusters along slender, arching stems. Native primarily to western Europe, especially the British Isles, bluebells thrive in moist, shady woodlands and grasslands, often forming striking blue carpets in spring. The leaves are long, narrow, and linear, emerging from the base and typically reaching 20 to 40 cm in length. Each flower has six petal-like tepals fused into a tubular shape with slightly recurved tips, giving it a delicate, drooping appearance. Bluebells bloom in mid to late spring and are rich in nectar, attracting bees and other pollinators. They spread both by seed and underground bulbs, forming dense colonies over time. Bluebells are protected in some regions due to habitat loss and hybridization, and they are associated with themes of humility, everlasting love, and the enchantment of the woodland.
